title: Are ESG Ratings Purely Subjective? Are They Fair?
sub_head: The ratings firms risk their reputations.
body:
In “S&P Hits U.S. States With Politicized Credit Scores” (op-ed, May 9), Marlo Oaks raises important questions about the future of the bond-ratings industry. Despite serious blemishes during the global financial crisis, nationally recognized statistical ratings organization (NRSROs) like Moody’s and S&P trade on their reputations and regulatory certification, both rooted in a clear and verifiable mandate: likelihood of contractual debt service “on time and in full.”
ESG ratings are different. Serious disagreements persist on environmental, social and governance goals, and there are equally serious issues with rubbery rating metrics.
